Situation1: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story:
The city’s sirens blared as I gripped the wheel, weaving the ambulance through a maze of honking cars. Dispatch had said the patient’s injury wasn’t life-threatening, but every second still felt urgent. My training drilled into me: safety first, no matter the pressure. I kept my speed in check, eyes darting between the road and the clock, feeling the weight of responsibility for my partner and everyone around us.

Then my phone buzzed. The news network. They needed me—now—to speak on air, to set the record straight about our cause before misinformation spread any further. I’d fought so hard for this moment, to have a platform, to educate the public. But I was behind the wheel, sirens wailing, city traffic thick as molasses. My heart pounded. If I answered, I’d be distracted, risking lives. If I ignored the call, I’d miss a rare chance to make a difference, to reach thousands.

The ambulance crawled forward, the phone vibrating insistently in my pocket. I felt split in two, torn between the duty to my patient and my cause, both demanding my full attention, both unwilling to wait.
